children.subject: I would have agreed with you except that harder courses within EECS/CS do not ever enforce prereqs. I don't think that the department should worry about students who might "potentially struggle". If students are signing up for the class, then it means they're willing to do whatever it takes to keep up and do well- they're ready to "struggle" if needed.

"except that harder courses within EECS/CS do not ever enforce prereqs."

Yes, but since Data 100 is now offered through CDSS, you should compare it to the policies for other data science classes offered through CDSS. In that regard, both Prob 140 and Data 102 have enforced prereqs. What EECS/CS classes do isn't applicable imo because they're a different department. 

'I don't think that the department should worry about students who might "potentially struggle".' 

There's of course some level of responsibility that students need to take, but the department and instructors absolutely should worry about students struggling. Why set them up for failure if at least some students who are going to struggle would struggle less or not at all if they were required to take prereqs first?
+1 to Ishaan. It is the same reason why EECS 70 should also hard-prereq EECS 16A+16B as they are essential classes to building mathematical maturity.

I wouldn't classify myself as someone "in the know" in that I had no prior info beyond the average student about the prereqs being enforced + I haven't talked to the people who made the decision about it, but I'll say that many students come in without at least some the prereqs and coreqs and consequently have a harder time in the class than they should. This very much includes EECS/CS majors who assume Data 8 isn't necessary because they've taken 61A and assume coding is all that's taught in Data 8 that's relevant (I'm not suggesting this category includes you since I don't know much about you Anon Helix) and have no prior knowledge of statistical concepts or experience with data science.

Now could at least some students self study this material and be fine? Yes, definitely. But this decision seems to prioritise not letting students who would struggle because they don't have the pre or co reqs come into the class until they have at least that foundational material under their belts

history.content:
Hi,

I'm a senior EECS major who has been denied enrollment into Data 100. I have already taken cs61a and ee16a with the exception of Data 8. Can faculty or students in the know clarify on why Data 8 is a STRICT prerequisite for Data 100? 

Thank you!
history.subject: Data 100
